aiOverview.content: The Exafluoran contamination in Bryn Bower continues to be a major environmental and social issue, with Hallman Inc.'s $19 million settlement proposal generating polarized opinions. Key documents highlight financial constraints, public health risks, and ethical responsibilities.

While 40% of contamination has been removed since the 1980s, full remediation below 10ppb is deemed cost-prohibitive at $300M. Hallman advocates for containment and city water expansion as cost-effective alternatives.

content: A contentious town hall meeting revealed deep divisions in Bryn Bower. Critics of the settlement, including residents and environmental advocates, argue that the deal absolves Hallman of full accountability for decades of contamination. Supporters highlight the financial practicality of the settlement, with some emphasizing the urgency of connecting more homes to city water to mitigate immediate health risks.

content: The CBBI strongly opposes the settlement, citing Hallman’s long-term negligence and advocating for the “polluter-pays principle.” They warn about the hidden ecological costs and long-term risks of Exafluoran contamination, including the eventual threat to city water reservoirs as the plume continues to spread. The CBBI dismisses the settlement as inadequate to address these broader concerns.

pages.title: Internal Document: 2020 Cleanup Cost Estimates
pages.author: WATER ENGINEERING LTD., Hydrogeology Experts since 1964

contents.content: Objective: 2020 Status report; Plume cleanup cost projection until 2030
Client: Hallman Inc., Bryn Bower, IL

Ground water pollution with Exafluoran® through leak in on-site evaporation lagoon from approximately 1965 to 1980, classified as slowmotion environmental disaster. Comprehensively monitoring of plume since 1986 via 52 city and company monitoring wells (status 2020). Cleaning efforts UV/peroxide treatment through 31 extraction wells near site, estimated 40% of toxin has been removed by 2020.

The spread of the plume has slowed down but continues. The water extraction prohibition zone (>20ppb) now covers nearly 30% of the city including parts of downtown. Current prediction for 2040: 10ppb for the water table of the entire Bryn Bower area (Downtown, Bryn Heights, Bower North, Bryn Hill); Bryn East will remain above the critical limit of 20ppb. Little to no pollution (<1ppb) expected for the water reservoirs.

Complete clean-up of the entire contaminated area to levels below 10ppb threshold is technically difficult and cost-prohibitive (>$300M). Focus should lie on contamination reduction at hazard site and broad-area concentration monitoring and containment of the >20ppb area.

We recommend 10 additional monitoring wells around the perimeter of the >20ppm contamination line, approx. 8.3 sq mi. Four to eight additional extraction wells in this area to reduce overall toxic load. Increase city water production capacity by 30% to successively phase out all well water use in Bryn Bower area regardless of contamination levels.

This expertise extrapolates the costs for three scenarios, varying in the intensity of the on-site Exafluoran® extraction. All three are in line with Hallman’s current (contested) legal obligations (2020). In addition to the continued financial commitment of the ongoing efforts, the cost projections range from $4.5M per annum to $11M per annum (= $45M-$110M until 2030).

pages.title: Hallman Plume Scandal; Tumultuous Townhall Meeting
pages.author: By Miriam Freeman

contents.content: The fact that there's a plume of toxic pollution slowly spreading throughout the groundwater of Bryn Bower has been a controversial topic since its discovery in 1984. Maybe mayor Dennis Upland really believed he would be able to resolve the issue with a $19M deal with the culprit, Hallman, Inc. But last night’s public hearing in Illy Hall demonstrated that the city is extremely divided on the issue.

Initially, an upbeat mayor briefly reviewed to a full house of more than 1,000 people the final terms of Hallman’s offer: The company cuts a big check, and the city will drop all pending lawsuits and deal with the contamination of the soil itself. The only exception is the highly contaminated Hallman production site in East Bryn, which the company will continue to clean up without the city’s financial help.

Christopher Taylor, the city’s head water treatment engineer, explained how the money would be used to get roughly 400 to 450 of those homes connected to city water whose well water is currently not contaminated enough to legally require it (below 20 ppb of Exafluoran). However, the city might be forced to connect them in the future anyway if the plume spreads further or if the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) lowers the critical limit.

When the microphones opened for public commentary after the 45-minute presentation, those parents in the audience with children in tow might have regretted staying. Not only did the discussion get more heated as the evening wore on, but the language filters also started to fail on both sides. Critics called the mayor a “liar,” an “idiot,” and other inappropriate insults. Supporters of the Hallman deal verbally retaliated with terms like “dimwitted” and “dopey.

Name-calling aside, some commentary did reveal the different sides of the issue. Real estate agent Robert Merton explained that property values have declined greatly on the east side. He said, “As realtors, we are trying everything we can to sell the property for as much money as we can, yet we must by law disclose that Exafluoran is in the area when a home is on well water. You might as well tell the buyer that somebody killed himself in the house. It has that kind of effect.” He argued that getting most houses connected to city water would help all homeowners because of a boost in local home value.

Mary Murski, who lives on a property where three houses share one well, countered that their well went down from 10 to 3 ppb over the last five years. She and her neighbors agreed that they don’t want city water. She said, “We love our independence and feel that there is no reason to let the Hallman crook off the hook.

Brenda Adams, a single mother of four who is renting a ranch on Kelcey Road, shared her moving story. The landlord never mentioned that the well water was poisoned with unsafe levels when she moved in five years ago. Last year, she read a story in this newspaper about the plume, and she called the city. The tests done the next day revealed that her water contained 35 ppb Exafluoran. The city clerk left her with forty 2-gallon jugs of clean water and instruction not to ingest any tap water. She was connected to city water last week. She said, “I came out here tonight because I think it is really important to hear my story because it is a personal thing.” “When we talk about the plume,” she closed, “we talk a lot about the standard and that’s a number, but that means something to people’s lives, to our kids, to all of us, right?” This might have been the only comment at last night’s meeting that got the applause of nearly everybody in the audience.

Many citizens expressed their mistrust in Hallman after decades of downplaying the problem and intimidating local officials who spoke out publicly. Peter Teal, for example, a retired accountant who worked in City Hall for three decades, raised doubts that the city water will remain uncontaminated. “This is what Hallman says, how convenient for them.” He ended his statement to some applause, “Let them pay for all the damage they have caused. It is that simple. No deal is the best deal.”

Robert Weisman, a former Hallman employee, implored everybody to use their common sense. He said, “You don’t have your head on straight. Hallman was on the verge of bankruptcy since 2009. They’ve had to lay off 20% of their workforce. Let’s take the money now while the company is profitable and get as many homes off well water as possible. We are here to stay, but Hallman might be liquidated before you know it.” As was true for most of the evening, boos and cheers ensued.

After 2 hours, a 15-minute break was called. Many people left, but those who stayed reseated themselves so that the pro and con sides were clustered together. The split was roughly even. This is when the discussion deteriorated further, and emotions and strong language started to dominate the remaining hour. Few, if any, new arguments were made. When the mayor finally closed the meeting after almost four hours of heated debate, he thanked everybody for coming and for “being so open about your opinions.” He probably left the meeting with a hunch that the deal he negotiated is in trouble.
After poisoning our city with Exafluoran for over 50 years and spending little to clean up the mess, Hallman Inc. wants to pass the buck to the city of Bryn Bower offering a $15 million “buyout.”
Here is why we strongly oppose this proposal
Hallman, and only Hallman, caused the catastrophe and should be held accountable for all current and future costs of the clean-up.

It is not only about the drinking water. What about the unknown costs of the plume to the flora and fauna? Hallman has opposed or suppressed all our efforts to investigate on its premises and surrounding areas.

Currently, the EPA considers 20ppb Exafluoran in drinking water an “acceptable level”. Until 1990, even 100ppb was acceptable. What is harmless? Some scientists now suggest that even 10ppb is too high. Exofluoran does not exist in nature. Therefore, ZERO ppb is the only level that is harmless!

Is it a coincidence the company is making the offer now? The lower the concentration levels, the more expensive it is to lower them further. The reduction from 200 to 100 ppb around the lagoon set the company back $8 million, the reduction from 100 to 50 almost $25 million. The clean-up is a bottomless pit. Don’t let the taxpayer foot the bill!

Hallman makes the public believe the city water is forever unaffected. That defies logic: The plume continues to spread and will eventually reach the water reservoir region. The problem is not limited to the remaining homes on well water.

pages.title: Interview with David Hallman Sr.
pages.author: Historian Rita Davidov interviewed David Hallman on Oct 3, 2015, for her book Industrialization of the Midwest 1900 – 2000, Chicago University Press 2017.

contents.content: Rita Davidov: Mr. Hallman, it is a pleasure to meet the founder of Hallman, Inc. in such good health on his 90th birthday Thank you for taking the time to sit down with me – I really appreciate it.
David Hallman: The pleasure is mine, Dr. Davidov. I have not spoken to many people about the company since my son sold it ten years ago.

RD: I am excited to ask you a lot of question about the company. First, I want to get a sense of how you’re doing. I hear you have a new great grandchild. I’m sure they’re keeping you on your toes and away from engineering.
DH: Oh yes, that’s a big new chapter in life. I’m blessed to share it with my wife, Elizabeth. […]

RD: I hope you don’t mind me asking how you feel about all the negative attention your company has gotten over the last, well, almost 40 years. National TV once dubbed Hallman the largest “well poisoner” in US history. How does that make you feel?

DH: Frankly, I am used to that, but it makes me sad that I rarely get a chance to tell the other side of the story or, better, one of the many other sides of it, the one that is most important to me anyway.
RD: Go right ahead, here is your chance. [laughs]

DH: Let me start by apologizing again to everybody who was affected by the contamination we still battle today and probably decades into the future. It is true, the leakage of the lagoon [i.e., retention pond on the premises of Hallman, RD] was tragic and seems careless in hindsight, but the procedure was standard and legal at the time – we are talking about the 1960s where we all thought nature will miraculously take care of itself. I don’t have to tell you how many million dollars Robert [Robert Hallman, his oldest son] and I have spent on the cleanup of the site so far. You never can do and pay enough to shed the perception of the public that you are a ruthless entrepreneur, trust me. But what people tend to forget is how important my patents and the company have been at the time. We built industrial pumps that stay functional even under the enormous pressure, heat, and unfathomable radiation. There is not a single nuclear power plant in the US that does not have at least ten of our reliable pumps installed. After my retirement, I read every detail about the Chernobyl disaster of 1986. If they had installed our pumps, the disaster would not have happened. I am proud of Hallman, Inc. for its contribution to making nuclear power in the United States the safest in the world.

RD: I am not sure a young family that moves to Bryn Bower cares much about the nuclear power plant pumps. The parents are rather worried about the health of their young children and the long-term risks of Exafluoran in their tap water.

DH: And I appreciate that! Of course, homeowners in Bryn Bower tend to forget how important our company was back then for stable economic growth and fret about the fact that they cannot drink their well water. Ironically, those wells get most of their power from Black Bend, the nuclear power plant 40 miles south from here – almost all its 200+ pumps were produced by Hallman 30 years ago in Bryn Bower. As much as I would like to turn back the clock and seal the lagoon properly in 1964, I cannot help but feeling that things are blown out of proportion here: There is simply no need in the 21st century to use well water in the larger Bryn Bower area, when you have city water with great quality from the nearby natural reservoirs. Sure, developers cannot cut costs anymore by using wells and septic tanks when they build new homes – as they shouldn’t! I am not belittling our mistake and responsibility but here is another tidbit: Elizabeth and I still live in the nice two-story colonial we built across the street from the factory in 1963 when Pigeon Grove was still a dirt road. Until 1991, we were using highly contaminated well water (150ppb, mind you!) until our house got connected to city water like almost every other home in Bryn East. Exafluoran is not more poisonous than rubbing alcohol and it evaporates quickly when heated. In the mid 1980s, we boiled a large pot of water with the range hood on full blast at 6 in the morning for 30 minutes. We used that water for everything from cooking and brushing our teeth. An inconvenience for sure, but not the end of the world even for our family with three teenagers. Many people who live on well water across the nation must do the same thing every day because well water quality and safety can be tricky.
RD: So, you think everybody should be hooked up with city water?

DH: Of course, and I don’t understand why this wasn’t done a long time ago. Kevin [Ingram, the former mayor, RD] tells me it is too expensive, and that many people don’t want to be hooked up to the city water. We are still good friends, but only because we avoid talking about the plume. He is a lot younger than me, but I still beat him on the golf course. […]

RD: Mr. Hallman, the time flew by! Of course, there are so many more questions regarding the history of the city and how it is intertwined with the destiny of your company. Thank you so much for this interview. I hope we find the time to continue this conversation. Thanks again.

pages.title: Offer to the City of Bryn Bower by Hallman, Inc.
pages.author: Statement of Endorsement by Local 4711 – 6/6/2020

contents.content: At the extraordinary general meeting on June 6, 2020, the CWU members employed at the central factory of Hallman, Inc. (Bryn East, Complex A/B), registered with Local 4711 of District 5, unanimously adopted the following resolution:

The CWU has a proud and long history of negotiating contracts on behalf of its members that address the concerns and the realities of the economic situation of Hallman, Inc. In difficult times, when the company faced bankruptcy, we restructured our agreements to help maintain competitive labor costs while continuing to provide good wages and benefits to our members, which allowed them to share in the profits when the company regained financial strength.
2. Support for Stability and Job Security:

Solidarity and stability always lie at the core of our strategy in negotiations on behalf of our members and all the employees at Hallman. Over the last eight years, we were able to sign long-term contracts to the mutual benefit of workers and the bottom line of the company. It is in this spirit that we endorse the management’s efforts to reduce the financial uncertainty resulting from the mandated cleanup efforts of the Exafluoran pollution, which have been ongoing for over thirty years.
3. Financial Transparency and Limits of the Offer:

Management has been very forthcoming with information and data about the financial situation of the company after the CWU agreed to strict confidentiality. After several discussions with CFO Allan Webber, we understand that the current offer to the city of Bryn Bower is at the upper end of what the company can spend without risking layoffs given the current financial parameters and prospective growth of the company.
4. Future Impact and Hopes for Negotiations:

It is our hope that the negotiations lead to a contract that gives the city of Bryn Bower immediate flexibility in executing plans to minimize the environmental impact of the pollution. We also hope that the increase in financial predictability will be reflected in the 2023 bargaining round when the current wage agreement expires.
